Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Student Travel Support for 29th IEEE International Parallel and Distributed Processing Symposium (IPDPS)

This award will support student travel to the 29th IEEE International Parallel and Distributed Processing Symposium (IPDPS). The conference will be held in Hyderabad, India, in May 2015. IPDPS is an international forum for engineers and scientists to present their latest research findings in all aspects of parallel computation. Supporting student travel to attend professional conferences and workshops is a very important mission of the NSF. The broader significance and importance includes fostering the next generation of researchers in this research area, as well as providing international experiences to build a globally-aware workforce. In particular, students will have the opportunity to learn state-of-the-art methodologies, be exposed to novel techniques, and interact with senior researchers in their areas of expertise.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 29th IEEE International Parallel & Distributed Processing Symposium (IEEE IPDPS ’15), held in Hyderabad, India on May 25-29, 2015, provided student travel grants to encourage participation by students where they can explore opportunities for technical growth and engage with the larger research community. The NSF award provided between $600 and $1,500 to 18 students from the United States to support their participation at IEEE IPDPS ‘15. 2 of the 18 students were female. 5 of the 18 students self-identified themselves as minorities. Travel awards were in the form of reimbursement post conference participation.

The PhD Forum was the focus of student engagement activities at IPDPS. Over 30 students participated in the open sessions. The following opportunities were offered: (1) Workshop on developing presentation skills, (2) Industry interaction session, (3) Panel on research and career planning, (4) Poster session open to all the conference audience, and (5) Workshop on improving writing skills. These official activities were in addition to the opportunity to network with leading researchers in academia and industry and to learn of the emerging research area in the field of parallel and distributed computing. These activities facilitated excellent opportunities for workforce development in the parallel & distributed processing and high performance computing areas.

Surveys were conducted to assess the satisfaction and perceived gain of the students. The feedback from participants was positive. Students stated that this would be their first participation in a major conference and they expected this to significantly help with their research. Over 16% of students who provided feedback on student participation at IPDPS were undergraduates. 29% of feedback respondents said they would not have been able to attend the conference without IPDPS travel support. In particular, Exit Survey respondents found the session on presentation skills useful and valued informal discussions with mentors over lunch.

The IEEE IPDPS organization committee has decided to continue and expand PhD Forum activities for future conferences. The IPDPS PhD Forum has become the model for other IEEE TCPP conferences to follow.
